results.title: Pipeline
results.creator_credit: Jack Fairbacher and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: Describes the work in laying out a 500 mile long pipeline from new oil-field in West Texas and Mexico to Illinois. Illustrates the difficulties involved and the care with which the work had to be carried out to avoid damage to the pipe itself or its protective wrappings. Includes a shot of the dynamite explosions used to clear a passage for the pipe-line through rock, also unusual machinery developed for specialised tasks.

results.title: Pioneer journey to the Oregon country
results.brief_description: A re-enactment depicting pioneer life in the West from the pint of view of a 10-year-old boy who makes the journey to Oregon with his family, at the close of the period when the Appalachians were a barrier to westward movement. Life on the trail, religious activities of the settlers, and the dangers and hardships encountered.

results.title: Pintubi
results.brief_description: The Pintubi tribe of the Northern Territory still live nomadically by hunting and gathering, and have little contact with white Australians. The film shows how the Administration is attempting to help them. Music composed and played by Don Burrows, narration by James Dibble.

results.title: Pink triangles
results.brief_description: Examines discrimination against lesbians and gay men, challenging some of society’s attitudes towards homosexuality in the process. Also looks at historical patterns of racial, religious, political and sexual persecution. Historical photographs, prints, engravings and archival film, including footage from Nazi Germany and the 1954 McCarthy trials, have been incorporated in this powerful documentary. During the middle ages pink triangles represented ‘victim’ resurfacing in Nazi Germany concentration camps to identify homosexuals before being reclaimed by gay activists towards the end of the 20th century as a positive symbol to represent their struggle.

results.title: Ping Pong
results.brief_description: An experimental abstract film. Animated sketches form and dissolve to background of music by percussion instruments. Stick figures and leg outlines glide and dance, flit and disintegrate into hail, through which a little girl wends with her umbrella. Occasionally the lively lines weaves into shapes that suggest the background of cymbals and drums.

results.title: Pine ways to profit
results.brief_description: The pine farmers in the South are learning to protect their forest as another source of income. The wood is used as chips, pulp, turpentine, poles, posts and stumps. They are at most risk from fire and prevention and cooperation between fire preventers and neighbours is essential. Methods of prevention and protection for seedlings are shown.

results.title: Pine Gap images
results.brief_description: A celebrations of documented images of the women’s protest camp at Pine Gap, Australian Northern Territory in November 1983. A series of images representing the feeling of some of the women acting for qualitative change and for world peace. A discussion starter about non-violent protest action.

results.title: Pilferage
results.brief_description: The problem of shoplifting in self-service stores. A grocer is seen trying various solutions. Points out that many legal technicalities are involved in direct accusation; that some means of dissuading shoplifters will also irritate good ccustomers; but continuous courtesy and helpfulness will drive away the bad customers while retaining the good.
